metadata.titleEn: Basic meteorological data of forest line on the east slope of Sygera mountains, at South-East Tibetan plateau Station  of Chinese Academy of Sciences (2018)
metadata.description:
1) Data content (including elements and significance): the data includes daily values of temperature (℃), precipitation (mm), relative humidity (%) and wind speed (M / s)
2) Data source and processing method; air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed are daily mean values, precipitation is daily cumulative value; data collection location is 29 ° 39 ′ 25.2 ″ n; 94 ° 42 ′ 25.62 ″ E; 4390m; underlying surface is natural grassland; collector model Campbell Co CR1000, collection time: 10 minutes. Digital automatic data acquisition. The temperature and relative humidity instrument probe is hmp155a; the wind speed sensor is 05103; the precipitation is te525mm;
3) Data quality description; the original data of temperature, relative humidity and wind speed are the average value of 10 minutes, and the precipitation is the cumulative value of 10 minutes; the daily average temperature, relative humidity, precipitation and wind speed are obtained by arithmetic average or summation. Due to the limitation of sensors, there may be some errors in winter precipitation.
4) In addition, it is convenient for scientists to update the atmospheric data in the future. This data is updated from time to time every year.
metadata.instructions:
The document is named as the South-East Tibetan plateau Station  of Chinese Academy of Sciences_ Basic meteorological data of forest line on the east slope of Sygera mountains
The format is excel

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zonation due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components. The southeastern Tibet's Sejila Mountain has a pronounced mountain vertical zonation feature: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, it includes broadleaf forest, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forest, coniferous forest, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are primarily based on the data from the Bayi Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical temperature lapse rate across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes in the region. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological modeling in this watershed area.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bingzhan, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line. Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to slope orientation: the west slope (south slope) and the east slope (north slope). The temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated, with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the west and east slopes. The estimation of the temperature vertical lapse rate and precipitation gradient is obtained through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and the temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Meteorological Bureau of Nyingchi City in the Tibet Autonomous Region. The data is from nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Lulang, Bing Station, and Laye Station, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ in 2016 and the highest in 2014, and an average λ of 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1, differing from the Selila Mountain and western slope, with the lowest λ in 2015 and the highest in 2017, resulting in an average λ of 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with a trend of increasing precipitation with elevation during the monsoon season, followed by a decrease and then an increase. In the non-monsoon season, the trend was a decrease followed by an increase, with a significant precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibetan station.

Verification.Question: Is there a potential for error in the winter precipitation data due to sensor limitations?
Are the temperature and precipitation gradients estimated using regression analysis based on elevation and weather data?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary data collection method for meteorological data in high-altitude areas automated digital acquisition, manual measurement, or a combination of both?

Concept Completion.Question: Where can datasets related to the meteorological conditions of 色季拉山 be sourced from?
Concept Completion.Answer: 巴宜, 尼池, 114站, 113站, 山口, 生态站, 鲁朗, 兵站, 拉月, 藏东南站站本部, 林线 station

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges might affect the accuracy of data collected at the 色季拉山 meteorological stations?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather meteorological data in high-altitude forest lines?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in high-altitude forest lines involves using instruments like the Campbell Co CR1000, with sensors such as HMP155A for temperature and relative humidity, 05103 for wind speed, and TE525MM for precipitation. Data is collected digitally every 10 minutes at a high-altitude site with natural grassland as the substrate.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating temperature and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in estimating temperature and precipitation gradients is the influence of various factors such as the limited number of high-altitude stations and the fact that most stations are located in valleys, which can affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of meteorological data collected at high-altitude forest lines?
Feature Specification.Answer: temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, wind speed, daily averages, daily totals, elevation of 4390m, digital automatic data collection

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges might arise in collecting accurate meteorological data at high altitudes with varying environmental conditions?
Feature Specification.Answer: inaccuracies in winter precipitation measurements, influence of location of stations in valleys versus ridges, accuracy of temperature lapse rates, accuracy of precipitation gradients

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are considered when estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: altitude of the stations, orientation of slopes, monsoon and non-monsoon periods

Quantification.Question: What is the frequency of data collection for meteorological variables in a dataset from the Linzhi region?
What is the range of average temperature lapse rates (λ) observed across different slopes in the Linzhi region over the years 2013-2018?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using daily average values in meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Daily average values in meteorological data collection, such as temperature, relative humidity, and wind speed, provide a simplified and aggregated measure of these variables over a 24-hour period. This approach reduces the complexity of raw data collected at shorter intervals, like every 10 minutes, and allows for easier comparison and analysis over longer time periods. It is particularly useful in understanding daily patterns and trends in weather conditions, which can be critical for ecological and atmospheric studies.

Definition.Question: How can regression analysis be used to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Definition.Answer: Regression analysis can be employed to estimate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients by analyzing the relationship between altitude and meteorological variables like temperature and precipitation. By using data from multiple meteorological stations situated at different elevations, researchers can perform regression analysis to derive rates of change in temperature and precipitation with elevation. This method helps quantify how these variables vary vertically across a mountain slope, providing insights into climatological and ecological patterns.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for daily temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, and wind speed at the Linzhi meteorological stations compare to those used at the Sejila Mountain Ridge line station in terms of equipment and frequency?
Comparison.Answer: The Linzhi meteorological stations and the Sejila Mountain Ridge line station both collect data on temperature, precipitation, and other meteorological variables, but they may differ in equipment models and data collection frequency. The Linzhi stations include multiple sites providing data for different elevations, while the Sejila Mountain Ridge line station uses specific instruments such as the Campbell Co CR1000, HMP155A, 05103, and TE525MM, with data collected digitally every 10 minutes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced when estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients between the eastern and western slopes of Sejila Mountain?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges on the eastern and western slopes of Sejila Mountain include differences in station placement and the number of high-altitude stations. While the eastern slope may face issues with limited stations located in valley areas, the western slope has fewer high-altitude data points, which can impact the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradient estimation.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in accurately measuring temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous terrains, and how might these affect the interpretation of climatic data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the limited number of high-altitude stations, which may not adequately capture the true lapse rates and gradients. Additionally, the placement of most stations in valleys rather than ridges could skew data, affecting the accuracy of climatic interpretations, particularly for high-elevation environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to potential inaccuracies in meteorological data collection during winter in high-altitude regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Due to sensor limitations, there may be certain inaccuracies in precipitation measurements during winter in high-altitude regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient be influenced by the geographical positioning of meteorological stations in mountainous areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors include the location of meteorological stations, with some being situated in valleys rather than on ridges, and the limited number of stations on the western slope and at high altitudes, which could affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences for data quality when using a 10-minute data collection interval for meteorological measurements in high-altitude forest lines?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a 10-minute data collection interval for meteorological measurements can lead to high-resolution data that captures short-term fluctuations in temperature, humidity, wind speed, and precipitation. However, sensor limitations, especially in winter, may introduce errors in precipitation data, impacting the overall data quality.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting meteorological data at different altitudes in mountainous regions like the Sejila Mountain?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include understanding the vertical variation of temperature and precipitation, enhancing knowledge of the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes, and providing reliable data support for hydrological modeling in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze both east and west slopes for temperature and precipitation gradients in mountain studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing both slopes is crucial to gain insights into the vertical gradient variations influenced by slope orientation, which helps deepen the understanding of the climatic and ecological differences and supports better ecological and atmospheric research in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of updating meteorological datasets regularly with new data points in high-altitude forest regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to maintain a large time-scale dataset that facilitates comprehensive studies in atmospheric physics, ecology, and atmospheric environment, while also providing updated and accurate data for ongoing and future scientific research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of meteorological data collected from forest lines, considering the potential challenges posed by high altitude environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data such as temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and precipitation are collected using instruments like the Campbell Co CR1000, HMP155A temperature and humidity probes, 05103 wind speed sensor, and TE525MM precipitation sensor. Data is collected every 10 minutes and then averaged or summed to daily values. The high-altitude environment can affect sensor accuracy, especially for winter precipitation, which might have errors due to sensor limitations. Regular updates to datasets help maintain their reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers address the variability in temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients when analyzing data from multiple meteorological stations in mountainous regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers utilize data from multiple meteorological stations located at different altitudes on various slopes of the mountain to study temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. Regression analysis is applied considering the stations' elevation to estimate these rates. The study accounts for factors like the location of stations in valleys versus ridges and the limited number of high-altitude stations that might influence the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Enablement.Question: What specific technological tools and sensors enable the collection of accurate meteorological data in high-altitude forested areas?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of accurate meteorological data in high-altitude forested areas is enabled by the use of digital automatic data collection systems such as the Campbell Co CR1000, with specific sensors like the HMP155A for temperature and relative humidity, the 05103 for wind speed, and the TE525MM for precipitation.

Enablement.Question: How do geographic factors and station placement affect the collection and accuracy of climate data in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: The accuracy of climate data collection in mountainous regions is affected by geographic factors and station placement, as most stations are located in valley areas, with only a few on ridges. This distribution, coupled with fewer high-altitude stations, can impact the derivation of accurate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies or approaches facilitate the estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountain ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountain ecosystems is facilitated by regression analysis of meteorological data from multiple stations, which accounts for the relationship between elevation and climate variables like temperature and precipitation.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected accuracy of meteorological data from high-altitude regions such as Sejila Mountain be affected by seasonal variations?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy of meteorological data, especially for parameters like precipitation, may be affected by factors such as sensor limitations in winter, which can lead to potential errors in recorded values.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the limited study on temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in mountain regions like Sejila Mountain, despite its ecological significance?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges such as the limited number of high-altitude stations, and most stations being located in valleys rather than ridges, can impact the ability to acquire accurate vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation.

Expectation.Question: Why would the anticipated outcomes of using multiple meteorological stations for analyzing vertical gradients be influenced by the geographic distribution of these stations?
Expectation.Answer: The distribution of meteorological stations across different altitudes and slopes (e.g., east vs. west slope) impacts the ability to accurately estimate vertical gradients, as the presence of more stations in valleys versus ridges can skew the data.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of current data collection methods used in the Linzhi area for understanding the vertical temperature and precipitation gradients?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of current data collection methods in the Linzhi area can be evaluated based on the comprehensive coverage of different altitudes and slopes. While the dataset includes data from multiple stations across the eastern and western slopes, the scarcity of high-altitude stations and the concentration of stations in valleys may hinder the precise estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. These factors could limit the understanding of vertical variations and necessitate improvements in station distribution to enhance data accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential for expanding datasets by integrating additional meteorological parameters or stations in the Linzhi area to enhance ecological and hydrological modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding datasets by integrating additional meteorological parameters or stations could significantly enhance ecological and hydrological modeling in the Linzhi area. By including more stations at various altitudes and slopes, particularly high-altitude and western slope regions, researchers could obtain more accurate and representative data. Additionally, incorporating parameters such as solar radiation, soil moisture, and evapotranspiration could provide a more holistic understanding of the region's climate dynamics and improve the reliability of ecological and hydrological models.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can ensure accurate temperature and precipitation measurements in mountainous regions.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods in mountainous regions like the one described involve using digital automated equipment such as the Campbell Co CR1000, which takes measurements every 10 minutes. Despite this, factors such as sensor limitations and the challenging environment can introduce errors, particularly in winter precipitation measurements.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how researchers can effectively estimate vertical temperature and precipitation gradients across different slopes.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers estimate vertical temperature and precipitation gradients by collecting data from multiple meteorological stations across different slopes and elevations. They perform regression analysis on temperature and precipitation against elevation to calculate vertical gradients, taking into account the geographical distribution of stations.
